WTO_tables.__EMPTY: Articles of apparel and clothing accessories
Synthetic resins, polymers, and polyesters (primary form)
Footwear with outer soles of rubber, plastics, or leather
Footwear with outer soles and uppers of rubber or plastics
Men’s/boys’ woven apparel (suits, jackets, trousers, shorts)
Fabrics, knitted or crocheted, of a width of > 30 cm
Plates, sheets, film, foil and strip, of plastics
Tubes, pipes and hoses, and fittings
Waste, parings and scrap of rubber

trade.title: Trade
keyTrends: {{country}} is a net importer of plastics across the value chain, with imports consistently three to four times higher than exports, indicating strong domestic demand and reliance on external sources.
Imports are dominated by final manufactured goods and primary polymers, while exports are concentrated in textiles and selected plastic products, indicating downstream manufacturing capacity.

Trade patterns show integration into Asian supply chains for inputs and African markets for exports, highlighting {{country}}’s role as a small, regionally connected processing and re-export economy rather than a primary materials producer.

Apparent consumption increased from USD 176 million in 2017 to USD 219 million in 2022, with a temporary contraction in 2020 followed by recovery, signalling growing domestic demand alongside economic rebound.
trade.summaryLeft:
Plastic Imports

A total of 1,580 million USD worth of plastic was imported to {{country}} between 2017-2022. In the latest reporting year 2022, the total imports reached value of 311 million USD, of which:

  • ~ 23% was plastic in primary forms
  • ~ 16% was plastic in intermediate forms
  • ~ 14% was intermediate manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 47% was final manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 0% was plastic waste.

Plastic exports

A total of 472 million USD worth of plastic was exported from {{country}} in the year(s) 2017-2022. In the latest reporting year 2022, exports reached a value of USD 93 million, of which:

  • ~ 1% was plastic in primary forms
  • ~ 16% was plastic in intermediate forms
  • ~ 16% was intermediate manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 67% was final manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 1% was plastic waste.
trade.summary:
Plastic trade trends

Between 2017 and 2022, Mauritius’s plastics trade expanded despite a temporary contraction in 2020. Total imports increased from around USD 255 to 311 million, while exports grew more modestly from USD 79 to 93 million, highlighting Mauritius’s role as a net consumer.

Primary plastics imports rose from roughly USD 54 to 73 million over the period, while exports of primary forms remained minimal (below USD 1 million annually). This suggests a strong reliance on imported resins and raw materials with little or no large-scale resin manufacturing.

Intermediate form and goods show moderate two-way trade. Imports remain higher than exports, but exports have grown steadily, particularly after 2020, indicating a functioning midstream sector that converts imported polymers into semi-processed products.

Final manufactured goods are the largest component of imports, increasing to nearly USD 147 million in 2022. Exports of final and intermediate plastic goods are notable for a small island economy, suggesting some domestic processing and re-export activity rather than purely import-driven consumption.

Trade in plastic waste is minimal relative to total plastics trade. Imports are limited while small volumes are exported, suggesting limited domestic capacity for specialised recycling or recovery streams.
trade.tradingPartners: Asia is {{country}}’s dominant trading partner, supplying most plastic materials and products, while exports are orientated mainly toward African markets, reflecting regional trade integration. Europe plays a secondary but important role on both import and export sides. The limited trade with the Americas and Oceania suggests that {{country}}’s plastics economy is closely tied to Asian supply chains for inputs and regional African demand for processed goods.
trade.productCategories: The World Trade Organisation’s database provides additional insight into the structure of {{country}}’s plastics economy. Here we focus on plastics, synthetic textiles, and rubber trade categories. HS-level data highlights a plastics economy closely linked to textiles and manufacturing. Imports are split between plastics and articles thereof (HS Chapter 39) and textiles, apparel and footwear (HS chapters 54-65), indicating strong demand for polymer-based materials and consumer goods. Key imported products include primary polymers and synthetic resins, plastic sheets and films, rubber tyres (HS Chapter 40), and footwear, reflecting reliance on imported industrial inputs and finished products. Exports are strongly dominated by textiles and apparel, with garments and knitted clothing accounting for most of the export value. This indicates significant downstream manufacturing capacity, where imported materials are converted to higher value consumer products for export markets. However, the scale of apparel exports compared to imports of synthetic textiles suggest that not all production is based on plastic-derived fibres. The data likely reflects substantial use of natural fibres and blended materials (including cotton, with imports approximately 178 million USD and exports 27 million USD in 2022, under HS Chapter 52), alongside synthetic inputs, indicating a diversified manufacturing base rather than one driven predominantly by plastics. Plastic exports are concentrated in packaging products, sheets and industrial components, indicating a smaller but functional plastics converting sector serving domestic and regional markets. Rubber (HS Chapter 40) trade remains largely import oriented, suggesting limited domestic rubber manufacturing capacity.

consumption.title: Consumption
consumption.content:
Plastic consumption is calculated as total imports minus exports, using UNCTAD data. The data shows that {{country}} is a consistent net consumer of plastics, with domestic demand exceeding export-oriented trade between 2017-2022.

Apparent consumption increased from around 176 million USD in 2017 to 219 million USD in 2022, representing moderate long-term growth despite short-term volatility. A pronounced decline in 2020 reflects reduced economic activity and trade disruptions during the COVID-19 pandemic, followed by a strong recovery in 2021–2022 as imports rebounded and consumption resumed.

Overall, the trend reflects a small but expanding plastics economy where consumption growth is driven primarily by import dependence rather than large-scale domestic polymer production and manufacturing.

wasteManagement.title: Waste Management
keyTrends: {{country}} has a growing plastic waste generation, estimated at roughly 56–62,000 tonnes from municipal solid waste (MSW) annually in 2020, rising to around 73,000 tonnes total plastic waste in 2022 when non-MSW sources are included.
Collection coverage is very high (around 96%), indicating strong municipal waste service performance compared with many countries.
Despite high collection, recycling capture remains limited (around 9% of plastic waste), with most collected plastics directed to controlled disposal rather than material recovery.
Around 86% of plastic waste from MSW is sent to controlled disposal facilities, while uncontrolled disposal remains low.
wasteManagement.content:
Plastic waste from municipal solid waste

An estimated 469 thousand tonnes of municipal solid waste were generated in {{country}} in 2020 (0.99 kg/person/day). Plastics account for approximately 13% of the municipal waste stream, producing around 56–62,000 tonnes of plastic waste annually. Per-capita plastic waste generation from MSW is estimated at 42–47 kg per year (about 0.12 kg/day), reflecting a consumption-driven waste profile typical of small island economies with strong tourism and import dependence.

A study on global waste management modeling showed 96% of municipal solid waste is collection coverage, leaving only 4% uncollected. This suggests effective waste service coverage and relatively limited unmanaged waste compared with many other small island states.

The annual plastic emission including both debris and open burning is estimated at 2,544 tonnes per year, which is equivalent to 2 kg/person/year. The estimated MSW generation per capita in {{country}} in 2020 was 0.99 kg per person per day. The municipal solid waste management system is largely disposal orientated. Around 86% of plastic waste (approximately 70,000 tonnes in 2022) is directed to controlled disposal facilities, while only about 9% is captured for dry recycling (approximately 2,900 tonnes in 2022).
wasteManagement.contentRight:
Plastic waste from non-municipal solid waste

Non-MSW sources add a meaningful share to the national plastics footprint. In 2022, non-municipal activities generated an estimated 11,000 tonnes of plastic waste, contributing to a total national plastic waste generation of about 72–73,000 tonnes.

This indicates that while municipal waste remains the dominant source, industrial and commercial sectors provide a significant secondary stream that may require dedicated collection and treatment pathways. The presence of non-MSW plastic waste suggests opportunities to improve circularity through sector-specific recovery systems, particularly for industrial packaging, commercial plastics, and production residues that may be cleaner and more recyclable than household waste.

environment.title: Plastics in the Environment
keyTrends: Plastic emissions to the environment are relatively small in absolute terms but still significant for an island context.
environment.content:
Beach litter

The national average count of plastic beach litter items in {{country}} was 1,337,026 items per km² in 2018.

A study which investigated the status of marine macro- and meso-litter in selected mangrove, seagrass and coral ecosystems of {{country}} island, in six sites from September 2020 to March 2021 found that plastics made up the highest composition for macro-litter (58%) and meso-litter (79%). Mean macro-litter density was highest at Melville mangrove ecosystem (5.60 ± 0.07 items/100 m²).

Common plastic items in the environment

A study conducted on meso-litter and microplastics sampling from October to December 2019 at 12 sites in {{country}} identified ‘shoreline and recreational activities’ as the main meso-litter source. Microplastics density was highest at the vegetation line and fragments, mostly blue-coloured, were the most encountered type of microplastics, and polyethylene was the most prevalent polymer type.
